raw_comment:
It doesn't seem to have occurred to anyone that the most prestigious colleges are that way because of who they admit, and changing that is not going to give an advantage to those who were formerly not admitted, but will simply make these schools no longer prestigious.

That is, it is plausible that Harvard graduates are desirable because Harvard screens its applicants for desirability, not because of the education they get once they are there. It's a similar fallacy for all highly selective schools - if a school only allows in the best students (for whatever meaning of best you like), the school and it's teachers don't have to be any good, because the best students will excel regardless.
ace_sentences: The most prestigious colleges are prestigious because of the people that they admit.
Changing who these colleges admit will not give an advantage to people that these colleges formerly did not admit.
Changing who these colleges admit will make these colleges no longer prestigious.
It is plausible that Harvard graduates are desirable.
Harvard screens its applicants for desirability.
Harvard graduates are desirable because Harvard screens its applicants for desirability.
Harvard graduates are not desirable because of the education that they get at Harvard.
A similar fallacy exists for every highly selective school.
A highly selective school allows only the best students.
The meaning of best can vary.
If a school allows only the best students then the school does not have to be good.
If a school allows only the best students then the teachers of the school do not have to be good.
The best students will excel regardless of the school.
